क्षेत्र के स्थानीय कौशल को मैप न किया जाए और उस क्षेत्र के युवाओं को विशेष समुदाय या क्षेत्र में विरासत में मिली उन विशेष कौशल में उत्कृष्टता प्राप्त करने के लिए प्रशिक्षित किया जाता है। सरकार ने उड़ान योजना को " उड़े देश का आ म नागरिक " टैग लाइन के साथ पेश किया। आधे अरुणाचल के लिए पासीघाट में एकमात्र बड़ा हवाई अड्डा बना। हालांकि , अब तक कोई प्रगति नहीं हुई है और उस हवाई अड्डे से अभी तक केवल दो उड़ाने भरी गई हैं। माननीय राष्ट्रपति का वक्तव्य है कि शिलांग - तुरा सड़क पूरे पूर्वोत्त र को आपस में जोड़ेगी। सरकार को यह समझाने की जरूरत है कि एक ही सड़क पूरे उत्तर पूर्व को कैसे जोड़ सकेगी सड़क सिक्किम राज्य के आलावा उत्तर पूर्व भारत के सात राज्यों को कैसे जोड़ सकती है। माननीय राष्ट्रपति की टिप्पणी है कि देश में सबसे लंबे समय तक नदी पुल - ढोला - साडिया ने 165 किलोमीटर तक असम और अरुणाचल प्रदेश के बीच की दूरी को कम कर दिया है। यह संख्या की भ्रमित करने वाला है। यदि नदी के दोनों छोरों के मध्य की दूरी केवल 3 किलोमीटर है , तो पूल 165 किलोमीटर की लंबाई कैसे कम कर सकती हैं। एनईएसआईडीएस योजना को 100 प्रतिशत केंद्रीय सहायता के साथ मंजूरी देने को बात की गई , पर हम सब यह सब जानते हैं कि यह योजना कोई नया प्रयास नहीं है , बल्कि एलएनसीपीआर को ही एक नया नाम दे दिया गया है। राष्ट्रपति का तर्क है कि उत्तर पूर्व में सुरक्षा की स्थिति में सुधार हुआ है और शांति वार्ता के लिए सरकार के प्रयास सराहनीय हैं। हालांकि . देश को एनएससीएन जैसे विद्रोही समूहों के साथ होने वाले वार्ता के बारे में देश को समझाया जाना चाहिए। शांति वार्ता के परिणाम लोगों के लिए खोले जाएं। सरकार को भी एनईसी पर अपनी नीति को स्पष्ट करना चाहिए। इसके अलावा आम बजट में भी सरकार ने उत्तर पूर्व को सेला पास के अलावा और कुछ नहीं दिया जिसका मैं विरोध करता हूँ। महामहिम राष्ट्रपति ने रक्षा के क्षेत्र में सरकार की सफलताओं का उल्लेख किया है। पूरे अभिभाषण के दौरान मैं अपेक्षा करता रहा कि महामहिम चीनी घुसपैठ पर क ुछ बोलेंगे , लेकिन अंतत : निराश हुआ। उपग्रह चित्रों से पता चला है कि चीन ब्रह्मपुत्र नदी को हटाने के लिए एक पानी के नीचे की सुरंग का निर्माण कर रहा है। अरुणाचल प्रदेश में सियांग / ब्रह्मपुत्र का पानी एकदम पारदर्शी है। नदी मोड़ने के कारण , पानी बेहद काला हो गया और ट्रबिडिटी , जो हमेशा 5 के नीचे रहती थी , 482 तक पहुँच गई। रेत , मिट्टी और लोहे को वजह से जलीय जीवों की मृत्यु हो गई , इस बर्ष प्रवासी पक्षी भी नहीँ आए। इसके अलावा , हाल ही में चीनी ने अरुणाचल के बिशिंग गांव में घुसपैठ कर दिया और इस तरह के घुसपैठ करते रहें। उन्होंने सीमा क्षेत्रों तक सड़क का निर्माण किया है और हमारी जमीन पर कब्जा करने को प्रतीक्षा कर रहे हैं। मैंने सरकार को अनगिनत पत्र लिखे , लेकिन राष्ट्रवादी सरकार ने तत्काल सामरिक महत्व के एक मुद्दे से आँखे फेर ली। इतना ही नहीं , हास्यास्पद तर्क दिया कि पानी के नीचे भूकंप के प्रभाव में नदी प्रदूषित हो गई है। जैसा कि माननीय राष्ट्रपति ने प्रकाश डाला , राष्ट्र निर्माण एक सतत प्रक्रिया है जिसमें देश के प्रत्येक नागरिक को एक विशेष भूमिका अदा करनी है। 130 करोड़ देशवासियों के सपने को पूरा करने के लिए हम सभी को पूर्ण समर्पण के साथ मिलकर काम करना होगा। मैं सरकार के प्रति बहुत आशावादी हूं और आशा करता हूं कि एक साथ काम करें और विकास की दिशा में राष्ट्र का नेतृत्व करें। जय हिन्द। * * श्री for the welfare of people, I have my doubts as to how effective these schemes are and how much truth lies in the tall claims made in the President’s speech. I would like to start by mentioning that despite the Government claiming to be one that aspires for ‘Sabka Sath, Sabka Vikas’ the President’s address has failed to address issues such as human trafficking, mob lynching, Schedule Castes and Schedule Tribes, women’s safety, huge farmer distress witnessed due to failed BT cotton seeds in various States, disability, malnutrition among children, huge gap in job opportunities and cases of Aadhar leakages, etc. I would like to know from Government what has been done on these fronts and to what end. The Government claims that it is nearing the completion of its 2019 target of Swachh Bharat, but I would like to ask the Government that while Swachh Bharat Mission- Gramin guidelines clearly envisages a yearly, country-wide, independent third-party assessment of the sanitation status of rural areas, why there has been no independent monitoring so far. ODF is more than just building toilets. It’s about bringing behavioural change in the people. But less focus has been given on the IEC- information, education and communication regarding the use of toilets. It has mostly been a race without quality check and verified data of ground reality. Various cases have been reported where the said subsidy of Government for building toilets has not been timely transferred, toilets built are not functional and people threatened by administration in the horde of achieving first rank in Swachhta mission at the cost of peoples’ lives. And most important of all, villages and areas where there is scarcity of drinking water for people, how are they going to spend water on every day toilet use. Government must take into account all these factors and not jump to declare victory over half achieved goals. At the beginning of the year, some seven manual scavengers died fixing a sewer line. Laws have not been able to curb the demeaning and life threatening job of manual scavenging. Last year, in August, Bezwada Wilson- social activist and Magsaysay award winner- had said that more than 12 crore toilets are being built under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, but the Government is relying on the services of manual scavengers who are overwhelmingly Dalit to clean these toilets. No mechanised and well thought out plan has been devised by the Government to tackle the cleaning of the septic tanks. We welcome Triple Talaq Bill was brought to provide justice and equal rights to Muslim women in their married life, but no effort was seen on the part of Government to bring about a legislation on the Women’s reservation. I want to ask the Government, if you really claim to be messiah of women by building toilets, bringing legislation on Triple Talaq and providing LPG connection, why not go ahead and bring the much awaited Women Reservation Bill. Why don’t take steps to curb rapes? The issue of women safety also received no attention of the current Government despite increasing and brutal incidents occurring every day. The rape of 8-month old girl in the National Capital is a shameful event for our society. We keep hearing news of infant and teenage rapes occurring around us but see no action being taken. NCRB data shows 38,947 rape cases of women in the year 2016. The 1,000 crore corpus fund, called the Nirbhaya Fund also remains largely unutilised. As a women, I welcome the decision of the Supreme Court where it recognised marital rape to minors below 18 years of age but it saddens me to know that for women about 18 years, there exist no way to receive justice if raped within the institution of marriage. I demand legislation by the Government for the same. The #MeToo campaign brought into light the stories of many women across the country who have suffered sexual violence at the hand of relatives or outsiders. The Economic Survey tells us that Indian population still prefers son, leading to some 21 million unwanted girls. This figure is also symbolic of cases of female foeticide practised in the country. And, all of this remain unattended by the Government. Human trafficking is again a very serious matter which needs due consideration, but has been highly neglected. Nearly 20,000 women and children were trafficked in the year 2016 and according to a report by the Ministry of Women and Child Development, there are 3 million sex workers in India of whom 40 % (1.2 million) are minors brought in the trafficking. I want to ask the Government that, on one hand, you talk of Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao, while on the other hand this is a cruel reality you refuse to even acknowledge. You boast of women empowerment, but don’t those lost lives deserve a better chance at life? In rural India, 23 % of girls have listed menstruation as the chief reason for dropping out of school. As many as 28 % of them said they do not go to school during their period because they lack clean and affordable protection, as India Spend reported on June 19, 2017. Yet no steps have been taken to promote menstrual hygiene among teenage girls, especially in rural areas. The demand of exempting sanitary pads from the purview of GST also went unnoticed by the Government. ASER reports bring out the ugly and distorted face of education system in the country where only 53 % of all 14 year old can read a simple English text and just 44 % can perform a simple division. Access to quality secondary education is still a dream for many in India. I was very upset when I learned of State Government’s decision to shut more than 1000 primary schools in Maharashtra. The logic given by Government behind the decision is completely baseless. I would like to ask the Hon’ble HRD minister what does he has to say about this? What is the reason behind low spending on the Rastriya Madhyamik Shiksha Abhiyan despite our country facing hardships in the secondary education? The schools in villages lack adequate infrastructure, with majority of them with no proper access to sanitation. There is a huge disparity in teacher- pupil ratio, wherein some schools do not even have regular teaching staffs. I want to ask the Government what good is all these schemes if it fails to change the reality of our education system which continues to be plagued by corruption, lack of effective teaching staff and curriculum and quality education. India is primarily an agrarian economy with more than 50 % of its population linked to agricultural production, whether directly or indirectly. In such a scenario, it becomes critical to focus on the development and innovation of agriculture and allied sectors. However, still a large number of Indian farmers depend on local moneylenders for loan at high rates of interests. Institutionalised money lending has still not been able to percolate the small and medium farmers. The lack of updated research has led to the failure of BT cotton crops and subsequent death of farmers in Maharashtra due to pesticide spraying. More than 50 % of the cotton crop got infected by pink bollworm in the state causing huge economic loss to the farmers. The bollworm infestation has occurred even as Indian farmers have adopted genetically modified seeds known as BT cotton that are resistant to the pest. These seeds were approved by Government in 2006. I would like to ask the Government, what you are doing to prevent another Yavatmal incident. I would also like to ask the Government, how many farmers of Yavatmal and Vidharbha were compensated through Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojna when the crops failed in the State. The current formula used by the Government for calculating MSP puts States like Maharashtra, having high input cost owing to low irrigation facility and low productivity, at a disadvantage as it takes into account the average input costs of all States. The Government launched e-NAM facility but how are farmers supposed to benefit when there is no internet connectivity in the rural and remote areas, no facility for transportation. Also, it limits the options of the farmers who are forced to sell their products at the APMC market at the available bidding prices even if they are getting better prices somewhere else. Export limitations again harm the interest of farmers. This results n huge debts and suicide. NCRB data states that a total of 12,602 persons involved in farming sector have committed suicides during 2015, accounting for 9.4 % of total suicides victims in the year. This Government promised to double farmer’s income by 2022, but the state of agriculture in the country sings the reverse tone. I come from a state which has a large number of farmers and would like to see some policy formation at the Centre for the welfare of farmers. Research and development has never picked up pace in agriculture due to negligence and hesitation on part of policy makers, due to which agriculture in India still suffers from perils such as weather and rainfall uncertainty, dwindling market prices and so on. Farmers suicide were highest in the past 2 years with as many as 2,414 farmers suicide in Maharashtra alone between January 1 and 31stOctober, as per the data reported by six divisional commissionerates across the States. Our Hon’ble President in his speech talked about simultaneous State and Centre elections. I am all for stable governance and people’s welfare but the idea of simultaneous election is just not the way to achieve it. One must remember that not only are elections a necessary condition for democracy, but they are lifeblood of our system. The proposal is, from start highly undemocratic and an attack on India’s federal structure as simultaneous election means that dominance of national issues will hurt the breadth of debates on people’s issue pertaining to particular State. And even if India was able to sync all Assembly and Parliamentary elections in the future, how does one stop the decoupling cycle from starting once again, as it did after the initial synced start in 1951-52? One of the major promises given by the Government in its 2014 manifesto was creation of one crore jobs. However, the Labour Bureau, which collects quarterly data on jobs created or lost in key sectors, showed only 1.4 new lakh jobs, had been created in these sectors in FY 2016 against 11 lakh jobs in FY 2013 and 3.7 lakh jobs in FY 2014. At 1.4 lakhs, the number of jobs created in FY 2016 is miniscule. It stands in stark contrast to the promise of one crore jobs per annum that the Prime Minister had claimed he would create or his other wild claims that he would create 15 crore jobs (approximately 2 crore jobs per year) by 2022. What is even more depressing is that the pace of creation of new jobs is not increasing but actually declining. Government went on a spree by launching slew of schemes such as Skill India, Make in India, Start-Up India, etc. but it has failed miserably in generating enough job opportunities for the citizens. In India, the population with disabilities is around 26.8 million, constituting 2.21 % India’s total population, as reported by 2011 population census data. But this significant population has not received much attention from the Government, whether we talk of 5 % GST on disabled equipment, or the discriminatory clause in the Foreign Affairs Ministry’s guidelines which prohibits disabled people from applying to Hajj. Instead of helping them out or making smart cities disabled friendly, the Government shows no empathy to the disadvantaged of our society. Even now, most buildings in India are not disability friendly, despite the Government of India, under the Accessible India Campaign, instructing all ministries to make their buildings accessible to persons with disabilities. There is no talk about making railways more disabled friendly or about how the reserved coach at the end of the train makes it inaccessible for the disabled population. India still lags behind in a big way when it comes to removing infrastructural, institutional and attitudinal barriers for their persons with disabilities, yet it found no mention in the President’s address. I want to raise another very important question to the Government regarding its decision to discontinue the scholarships given to SC and ST girls under the National Scheme of Incentives to Girls for Secondary Education from March 31. Is this your way of educating girls in the name of Beti Padhao? I am very confused. This Government says something else and then go ahead and does just the opposite. The Government has also not been releasing the due funds for Dalit and Tribal students under the post-metric scholarship. I ask again how is this Sabka Sath Sabka Vikas? Ours is a country where we highly respect our elders and touch their feet to show our respect. Considering India is expected to be home to 300 million elderly people by 2050, and with India shifting towards nuclear families, we need welfare schemes that target our elders and enable them to lead a comfortable life away in absence of care from their children. However, I was shocked to learn that the Centre supported Integrated Programme for Older Persons has seen a decline from 269 homes in 2012-13 to a dismal 137 in 2014-15 despite the growing population of senior citizens in the country. There is an urgent need to provide affordable housing and healthcare to the older to enable them bring Government’s attention to the rising prices of diesel and petrol, since the BJP-led NDA Government has come to power making it costliest in the Southeast Asian countries. Taxes currently constitute 45 % - 52 % of the retail price of auto fuels, thus making diesel and petrol costly for Indians. Ever since this Government has come into power, excise duty has been raised 9 times between November 2014 and January 2016 itself. They refuse to bring petrol and diesel into the tax ambit, which would significantly reduce the price burden of oils for consumers. Everyday fluctuation in the prices badly hurts the consumers. The so calledACCHE DINseems a farfetched dream to the common man and poor under this Government regime. Healthcare is an important parameter when you measure the demographic potential of a country. But last year’s negligence leading to death of children in Gorakhpur due to alleged disruption of oxygen supply and cases of excessive billing and negligence in big corporate hospitals, such as the case of dengue death in Fortis Hospital, Gurugram are proofs of the systematic failures in public health services. National Family Health Survey, 2015-16 also revealed that less than one-third (29%) of households have at least one member covered under health insurance or health scheme. Most Government hospitals do not have adequate infrastructure as reported by Rural Health Statistics 2017, with only 11% of sub-centres and about 13% of primary health centres functioning according to Indian Public Health Standard. The Janani Suraksha Yojna which provides cash incentive of Rs1400 to poor women for institutional delivery does not cover even half of the expenses that women have to bear. I would urge the Government to strengthen the delivery of public health services by filing the gap of acute shortage of qualified professionals and medical supplies. Extreme malnutrition resulting in stunted growth of children is another issue plaguing our society. I would ask the Government to focus on improving the health of all those children by providing nutritious meal. I thank the President for outlining the goals and achievements of the Government, but I also sincerely hope that the Government would now focus on the aspects so far neglected in their tenure. * * डॉ . : ( लातूर ) सुनील बलीराम गायकवाड महामहिम राष्ट्रपति रामनाथ कोविन्द जी ने हमारे दोनों सदनों के सदस्यों के सामने अभिभाषण किया। हमारे देश के लोकप्रिय प्रधानमंत्री श्री नरेन्द्र मोदी जी और माननीय राष्ट्रपति जी ने पूरा भाषण हिन्दी में दिया। हमारी राष्ट्रभाषा हिन्दी है। मैं बहुतबहुत धन्यवाद देता हूँ कि हमारे देश की राजभाषा में आपने अपना अभिभाषण किया। बहुत धन्यवाद देता हूँ कि हमारे देश की राजभाषा में आपने अपना अभिभाषण किया। - परम पूजनीय संविधान निर्माता डॉ . बाबा साहब अंबेडकर जी का उल्लेख किया गया है। समाज में आखिरी आदमी जो दीन , दलित , गरीब है उन्हें समान अधिकार , अधिक उन्नति करने के लिए इस बजट सेशन के अभिभाषण में खास उल्लेख किया गया है। पिछले तीन सालों में स्वच्छ गृह स्वच्छ भारत की दिशा में बहुत काम कर रही है। प्रधानमंत्री जी के नाम से प्रधानमंत्री उज्ज्वला गैस योजना से गरीब के घर में गैस का मुफ्त कनेक्शन दिया गया। करोड़ों गरीब परिवारों को इसका लाभ मिला है। मेरे लोक सभा क्षेत्र में 5 -7 हजार परिवारों को उज्ज्वला गैस योजना का लाभ मिला है। माननीय प्रधानमंत्री जी ने इस योजना के तहत बहुत बड़ा सेवाभावी काम किया है। मेरे लोकसभा क्षेत्र में 50 हजार से ज्यादा लोगों को प्रधानमंत्री घर योजना का लाभ पिछले 3 साल में मिला है। लातूर शहर में नगर पालिका के लिए पानी की बड़ी समस्या थी , उसके लिए 1 00 करोड़ की राशि अमृत योजना के तहत मिली है। गरीबों के हित के लिए भी महत्त्वपूर्ण योजना माननीय प्रधानमंत्री जी ने शुरू की है। मेरे लोक सभा क्षेत्र लातूर में आज तक बहुत ही गरीब रोगियों को करोड़ से ज्यादा राशि माननीय प्रधानमंत्री सहायता कोष से मिली है। हमारी सरकार के मुखिया माननीय प्रधानमंत्री जी का आभार जितना भी माने वह कम ही होगा क्योंकि लातूर में पानी की कमी से लोगों को समस्या हो रही थी। रेल से पानी देने का ऐतिहासिक काम भी माननीय प्रधानमंत्री जी ने किया। लातूर में रेलवे स्टेशन पर अब आस - पास लगभग 9 नई ट्रेनें शुरू हो गई हैं। इसके लिए भी उन्हें ही धन्यवाद देता हूँ। हमारे मोदी जी की सरकार ने तीन तलाक का विधेयक पास किया है। अब तो दुनियां का सबसे बड़ा आयुष्मान मेडीक्लेम के तहत 5 लाख तक खर्च साल में सरकार की तरफ से दिया जाएगा। गरीबों के प्रति संवेदना के लिए माननीय प्रधानमंत्री जी को धन्यवाद देता हूँ। मेरे लोक सभा क्षेत्र लातूर में भी महाराष्ट्र में हमारी सरकार ने दो सु पर स्पेश्येलिटी हॉस्पिटल का निर्माण किया है। मेरे लातूर क्षेत्र में 200 बेड का सुपर स्पेश्येलिटी हॉस्पिटल का निर्माण जीरो से शुरू हुआ है। इस हॉस्पिटल का फायदा इतना होगा कि मेरे लोक सभा क्षेत्र के आस - पास के राज्यों , आंध्र , तेलंगाना , कर्नाटक के गरीब रोगियों को इसका फायदा होगा। माननीय नितिन जी के हाथों से मेरे लोकसभा क्षेत्र में राष्ट्रीय राजमार्ग निर्माण के लिए 9 हजार करोड़ का निर्माण कार्य शुरू हुआ है। नई रोड लाइन के लिए भी अच्छी मात्रा में राशि देने का काम हमारी सरकार ने किया है। एक विकास और विकासशील देश की सरकार मोदी जी के नेतृत्त्व में अपने देश की जनता की प्रगति के लिए प्रयासशील है और देश के गरीबों को मुख्य प्रवाह में लाने का काम कर रही है। मैं माननीय राष्ट्रपति जी के अभिभाषण का स्वागत करता हूँ तथा धन्यवाद देता हूँ। एक प्रगतिशील राष्ट्र के निर्माण में मोदी जी की सरकार का बहुत बड़ा योगदान है। इस बजट सेशन के अभिभाषण का मैं स्वागत करता हूँ और महामहिम राष्ट्रपति जी को बहुत बहुत धन्यवाद देता हूँ और समर्थन करता हूँ। धन्यवाद। * * SHRI GOPAL SHETTY (MUMBAI NORTH): I am submitting my opinion, thoughts and including myself to Hon'ble President's Address to the nation as a vision road map of the development. तीन बातों का जिक्र करना चाहूँगा। सबसे पहले अपने किसान भाईयों का , उनके योगदान का और उनकी जरूरतों का जिसे हम अंग्रेजी में Farmers Distress कहते हैं। भारत एक कृषि प्रधान देश है और देश की अर्थव्यवस्था पर इसका योगदान महत्वपूर्ण होता है। राष्ट्रपति जी ने सही कहा कि किसानों की मेहनत , लगन और हिम्मत से तथा सरकार के पूर्ण योगदान से इस बार कोई 275 Million Tonnes Food Grains और 300 Million Tonnes of Horticulture का उत्पादन हुआ है जो कि एक Record है। सरकार भी 2022 तक किसानों की आमदनी दुगनी करने के लिए प्रतिबद्ध है। किसानों को बार - बार Minimum Support Price for Crops, खाद इत्यादि में सब्सिडी या फिर ऋण - माफी नहीं चाहिए क्योंकि ये स्थायी हल नहीं हैं। उसे तो अपनी मेहनत की पैदावार का लागत से ज्यादा सही मूल्य मिलना चाहिए जो स्थायी हो ताकि वह इज्जत से जी सके और उसे आत्महत्या के लिए मजबूर न होना पड़े। जरूरी सुविधाएं मुहैया कराने का काम सरकार का है जो अपना दायित्व निभा रही है। हमारे वित्त मंत्री जी ने इस बार के बजट में किसानों की तरफ खास ध्यान देते हुए उन्हें जो सहूलियतें दी हैं , वे काबिले तारीफ हैं। इसके लिए मैं वित्त मंत्री अरुण जेटली जी का धन्यवाद करता हूँ। राष्ट्रपति जी ने पाकिस्तान द्वारा कश्मीर में दहशतगर्दों की घुसपैठ और हमारी सुरक्षा एजेसियों के द्वारा स्थिति का सामना करने का भी जिक्र किया है। कश्मीर आज एक गंभीर मसला बन गया है। भारत की तमाम कोशिशों के बाबजूद पाकिस्तान अपने नापाक हरकतों से बाज नहीं आ रहा है। वह सीमा पार से आतंकी भेज रहा है , कश्मीर के नौजवानों में धार्मिक उन्‍माद पैदा कर निर्दोष लोगों की हत्याएं करा रहा है और कश्मीरियत को बर्बाद कर रहा है। कश्मीरियत बनती है घाटी में सूफीवाद से , जम्मू में Hinduism से और लद्दाख में Buddhism से। आज कश्मीर की हालत यह हो गई है कि '' मर्ज बढ़ता गया , ज्यों ज्यों दवा की '' , जब दवा से काम नहीं बना तो हमने दो बार Surgical Strike की , लेकिन सब बेअसर। पाकिस्तान है कि सुधरता ही नहीं। अब जरूरत है किसी Major Operation की। मुझे उम्मीद है कि सरकार सही समय यर उचित कार्रवाई करेगी। कश्मीर के कुछ जनता द्वारा चुने हुए प्रतिनिधि जिनमें विधानसभा तथा लोकसभा सदस्य भी हैं , वे कश्मीर का भारत में विलय को चुनौती दे रहे हैं और अलगाववादी ताकतों के सुर में सुर मिला रहे है। वे भूल जाते हैं कि उन्होंने सदस्य बनते वक्त भारत के संविधान के प्रति वफादारी की Oath of Affirmation उठा रखी है , तो अब वे भारत व िरोधी बयान क्यों दे रहे हैं। ऐसे सदस्यों की सदस्यता फौरन रद्द होनी चाहिए और उन पर देशद्रोह का मुकद्दमा चलाना चाहिए जो कश्मीर को Disputed Territories बताते हैं । मैं इन सदस्यों को बता देना चाहता हूँ कि कशमीर पर धारा 370 एक Temporary Provision है और इसे भारत की संसद की मंजूरी भी नहीं मिली। अगर कश्मीर में प्रधानमंत्री के नाम को बदल कर मुख्यमंत्री और सदरे - रियासत को दूसरे राज्यों की तरह Governor, कर दिया जा सकता है तो धारा 370 को भी समाप्त किया जा सकता है। अगर जरूरी हो तो सरकार को संविघान में संशोधन करके धारा 370 को समाप्त करने की जल्द से जल्द कार्यवाही करनी चाहिए। प्रधानमंत्री को मेरी सलाह है कि अब समय आ गया है कि हमें कशमीर में पीडीपी का साथ छोड़कर कश्मीर में राष्ट्रपति शासन लगाना चाहिए। Tripple Talaq मुस्लिम महिलाओँ के लिए एक वरदान साबित हो रहा है। मेरा सरकार से अनुरोध है कि अब Uniform Civil Code लागू करने के लिए भी यह साहसी कदम उठाएं। घरेलू उड़ानों में इस समय भारत संसार में तीसरे नंबर पर है। हर बड़ा शहर एक - दूसरे से हवाई सेवा से जुड़ा है। आम नागरिक आसान और सुविधाजनक हवाई सफर कर सके , सरकार ने एक योजना शुरू की है जिसका नाम है ' उड़े देश का आम आदमी ' । करनाल एक ऐतिहासिक तथा औद्योगिक शहर है। यह मेरा सौभाग्य है कि यह मेरा चुनाव क्षेत्र है। करनाल में हवाई पट्टी बनाने को मंजूरी मिल चुकी है। अब जो भी औपचारिकताएं Civil Aviation Ministry और हरियाणा सरकार को पूरी करनी हैं , वह फौरन पूरी करें और जनता तथा व्यापारियों की मांग को ध्यान में रख कर जल्दी करनाल में हवाई - While speaking about construction of toilets under the ‘Swacch Bharat Mission’, various connected issues like ground water contamination due to diffuse source pollution and the inhuman practice of manual scavenging still plague this sanitation movement, and are not being addressed sufficiently. Various on-ground reports have showed that the haphazard diffuse waste management could potentially contaminate ground water sources, which once contaminated can spread mass disease, and create havoc in water supply in villages. Sanitation and water need to be looked at from a holistic perspective, where in the pursuit of the former, the health of latter cannot be ignored or sacrificed. I would like to commend the inclusion of the issue of maternity leave in this Address by the Hon'ble President. However, the issue of paternity leave also needs to be raised along with the positive reform of maternity leave that this Government is planning. As this year's Economic Survey revealed that there is a widespread preference of parents towards a male child, addressing issues of gender equality and parity while breaking out of the patriarchal system, becomes a necessity. India is also faring very badly on the World Economic Forum's Gender Gap Index, where we are in the 108thposition, behind countries like Bangladesh and China. Increasing share of women's participation in work force can only be guaranteed when our policies start looking at child-bearing as a 'family' responsibility, rather than only of the woman. An initiative like 'paternity leave' would have widespread social impact in conveying the message that the responsibility of the home and child is not that of a woman alone, but also that of a father. On the health sector performance of this Government, including the expenditure by States, India spends 1.4% of its GDP on health, which is not nearly sufficient for a nation with the highest population of stunted children at 48.2 million. Households still contribute around 69% through out-of-pocket expenditure on health needs. Our expenditure on curative care in estimated to be 80.4% while only 9% is spent on preventive care. As a policy objective, not only does our expenditure on health need to increase, but focus must also be on preventive care. Now, coming to the economy and credit availability, in spite of schemes like Pradhan Mantri Mudra Yojana, the problem of lack of credit is faced by MSME. Data on credit disbursed by banks shows that out of a total outstanding credit of Rs.26,041 billion as in November 2017, 82.6% of the amount was lent to large enterprises and MSMEs got only 17.4% of total credit. MSMEs not only contribute the most to GDP but also create maximum employment, yet they have faced existential pressure from GST and demonetization. At such times, there has to be a policy focus on strengthening credit atmosphere for small and medium enterprises. On the front of welfare of tribals, although it is a welcomes move to increase Minimum Support Price of Forest produce for tribals, the Government still neglects the impact that levy of GST is having on their livelihoods. Certain forest produces which is collected by Tribals from my state Odisha like Sal leaves, still fall under the purview of the Goods and Service Tax. Tribal economic activities involving collection of forest produce are subsistence occupations which give financial independence to many tribal women in my state. Such an activity when taxed becomes wholly unviable for those poor folk who rely on this for subsistence. One cannot deny that Aadhar is now being used for eliminating middlemen but it has also brought with it a myriad of security and data protection concerns which were addressed. The misuse of data by private entities, lack of enough safeguards, information or redressal mechanisms are plaguing this biometric identity system introduced with much fanfare across the nation. Reports of denial of Government services and even private services due to lack of Aadhar are coming forth, and this need to be tackled at the earliest. Moreover, it paints a very sad picture for the agri-sector in the light of climate change, stating that the farmers may lose 20-25 per cent of their revenues to the drastic changes in weather in the medium term. Under these conditions, it is important to insure the farmers against changing weather by dramatically extending efficient irrigation techniques. There are reports that the Centre has constituted a committee to formulate standards for cup lump rubber, a step which will spell doom for the domestic plantation sector both commercially and environmentally. Despite this, the Ministry still seems to focus more on modernization of the facilities in the coaches than on maintenance and repair of tracks. The Address also fails to mention the rising income inequality in the nation. A report released by Oxfam highlights the widening wealth gap between haves and the have-nots with the richest 1% cornering 73% of the wealth generated in the country last year. This underscores the need for the government machinery to effectively reach out to be underprivileged population to help them meet their needs. BIJU (ALATHUR):The maiden presidential address of Hon. President, contrary to my high expectations has gone astray. It has nothing new to offer and a mere continuation of the past three year’s rhetoric of the NDA Government. It is presented as pro-poor, but in fact a facade to the crony capitalism initiated by the UPA and vigorously pursued by the NDA Government. Apart from highlighting and reiterating some of the flagship programmes, the speech was full of hollow promises. Sadly, even these programmes have become a mockery of what it had offered initially. Take the case of Make in India, political sloganary mission and a type of Swadeshi movement covering 25 sectors of economy, launched in 2014 with much hype to encourage companies to manufacture their products in India. It is shameful to this emotional slogan that still, in case of medical and electronics, we depend on imports for 90 per cent of the country's needs. Japanese steel and engineering companies are the major supply contractors for a 17 billion dollar Indian bullet train project, undermining a key component of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's economic policy- a push to 'Make in India'. It brings little cheer that the World Economic Forum (WEF) ranked India among the top 30 on a global manufacturing index. The irony is that India is behind smaller countries like Czech Republic and Austria, both smaller than Gujarat in size, for example. What is worth noting is the exclusion of key issues that are craving for the immediate intervention of the Government, such as Agricultural distrust, growing unemployment, inflation, malnutrition, rising atrocities against SC/ST, etc. Hon. President categorically said that his Government is committed to double the farmers' income by 2022. But what is the real picture? The year 2017 was marked by several farmers' protests nationwide, with a few turning violent and many had been killed in police firing. The same year in New Delhi, 184 farmer groups came together from Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Punjab and Telangana to take part in a 'protest walk'. The protest once again highlighted the plight of farmers and the extent of agrarian distress. He also pointed out that it is the result of the hard work of farmers that there has been a record production of more than 275 million tonnes food grains and over 300 million tonnes of fruits and vegetables. But, he maintains a studied silence on the plugging price of agricultural products and alarming rise in number of farmers’ suicides in India. The agriculture growth rates have been unsteady in the recent past. For many crops, the farmers are not even able to get the MSP announced by the Government, which should really be the floor price. In just the current season, the loss due to the gap between MSP and actual price is estimated to be about Rs. 36,000 crore for farmers across India. Thousands of farmers commit suicide due to the falling prices and shrinking subsidies. In January-October 2017 period itself, Maharashtra reports 2,414 farmer suicides. The Neo Liberal Reforms have taken a toll on our agricultural sector. Cutting of subsidies, poor access to formal rural credit system, ineffective compensation policies and above all, corporatisation of agriculture has broken our agrarian economy. The discontent from the various sections should be seen in this light of crumbled agrarian structure of our country. Unemployment is also a major hurdle to our development. In India, around 1.85 crore people enter into the labour market. When NDA came to power, their biggest promise to the youth in India was the creation of 2 crore employment opportunities every year. But what has happened? TheTuglaqiandecisions of demonetization and GST has taken away around 2 crore employment opportunities every year that would have been a breather for the struggling unemployed youth in our country. Inflation is another challenge that the Government could not handle with. Consumer prices in India rose to a 15 month high in 2017 due to the ongoing seasonal surge in vegetable prices and an unfavourable base effect from last year, breaching the Reserve Bank of India's medium term target for inflation. The benefit of price slash of international crude oil price has not been transferred to the consumers and the economy. Instead, the Government is transferring the benefits to the corporate and augmenting the inflation. It is expected that, at this rate, in all likelihood, the inflation rate would cross double digits this year. Wholesale Price Index (WPI) is at its all time high. While WPI in 2016 was 1.3%, it has doubled in 2018 with 3.6%. The price of food articles has been increased from 3% in 2016 to 4.3% in 2017. The World Bank estimates that India is one of the highest-ranking countries in the world for the number of children suffering from malnutrition. The prevalence of underweight children in India is among the highest in the world. While aggregate levels of under nutrition are shockingly high, the picture is further exacerbated by the significant inequalities across states and socio-economic groups- girls, rural areas, the poorest and scheduled tribes and scheduled castes are the worst affected. The 2017 Global Hunger Index Report ranked India 97thout of 118 countries with a serious hunger situation. But, allotment in ICDS scheme has been again reduced in this budget, which is highly condemnable. In the Health front, The National Health Protection Scheme promises Rs. 5 lakhs per year per family for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization and aims to cover 10 crore families. The Mega Health Insurance Scheme announced in Budget 2018 is largely geared towards the corporate healthcare industry's interests. It is more an election gimmick than a real solution to India's health needs. If we compare it with last year's revised estimates, the increase in the budgetary outlay for the health sector is trivial, and in real terms probably stagnant. On some key components, especially the National Health Mission (NHM), there is a decline in allocations. This Budget continues with the recent trend of tinkering at the edges of the problems that confront Indian education, which is plagued with many serious issues aside from the overall lack of funds. Increase of the 3% education tax to a 4% 'health and education' levy would bring an additional Rs. 11,000 crore to Government coffers. This shows the Government is in no mood to prioritize education and has shifted that responsibility to the public. The end result is the complete corporatization of education and depriving the marginalised and weaker sections from it. We had strong PSUs that helped us to withstand the perils of the latest Global economic crisis. Dismantling the public sector became a part of the Government agendas since 1991 with the official advent of neoliberal policies under the Congress Government. The concepts of self-reliant economy, economic sovereignty, balanced regional development, social justice, etc. were sought to be given a go by. The Modi Government has intensified these policies. It is determined to dismantle the entire public sector in the country, conceived to achieve 'commanding heights' of our economy. Public sector today is the respiratory of huge national assets including land and minerals, vital infrastructure and huge productive forces. It is the wealth of the nation. The decision of the BJP led Government to allow 100% Foreign Direct Investment in such strategic sectors of our economy like defence, railways, telecom, civil aviation, satellites, power, petroleum, mining, coal, etc. is nothing but anti-national in character. According to the Credit Suisse Research Institute's Global Wealth Report, 1% of rich holds the 73% of the wealth of our country and our country is not going in the right direction. This huge disparity among the people of our country shows the unhealthy situation of our economy. In 2014, it was 53%. I conclude with a firm conviction that mere promises will not help in the upliftment of the poor in our country. मनायें तब तक हम इन लक्ष्यों को प्राप्त कर लें। राष्‍ट्र के हित में राष्‍ट्र निर्माताओं के सपने पूरा कर हम देशवासियों को सरकार की ओर से सच्ची श्रद्धांजलि अर्पित करें। धन्यवाद। * * DR. RATNA DE (NAG) (HOOGHLY):While thanking the President for his Address on 29thJanuary, 2018 to both the Houses of Parliament, I would like to make a few pertinent points. President's Address was deeply disappointing primarily because it is contrary to the ground realities. It is claimed by the Government that it is envisioning a New India. How can we ever dream of New India when our farmers are distressed (a farmer is committing suicide in every 40 minutes), a large scale unemployment, burden of demonetization and GST on the economy, etc? It is also stated in the Address that the Government is committed to doubling the income of farmers by 2022. In fact, this Government promised to double the farmers' income from 2014 onwards. We are in 2018, and yet there is no distant sign of it emanating from the shadows. Now, it is talking of 2022! For me, it looks like a joke on the people, and more so on farmers. We find in the Address a spate of schemes. It is like rhetoric with no substance. Every section of the society is reeling under a problem - be it ever growing price rise, petrol price rise, half-baked GST killing small entrepreneurs,Babusmonitoring GST indulging in corruption, as is reported in the press, etc. Nothing seems to be moving in the right direction. Finance Minister claimed that note ban led to wider taxpayers base, let him come with facts with how it affected the economy and not destroyed unorganised sector, etc. The other disturbing trend brewing and taking the shape of dangerous proportion is Kashmir violence. Cross border infiltration is growing, and relationship with Pakistan has deteriorated since this Government took over. There is no clear Kashmir policy with the Government. It seems there is no stopping of disturbances in the Valley. The policies being followed by the Centre and the J&K Government are destroying the normal life of the people of the Valley. Their tourism, which is their only main occupation, is in jeopardy. Who is responsible for it? Is the Centre or State responsible or accountable? There is also a talk of holding simultaneous elections. Is it at all feasible? Has any initiative been taken by the Government so far? Is there a consensus among political parties? Most of the parties, save the BJP, are not in favour of it. Almost every six months or so, one or two State Assembly elections are held. Though Law Commission suggested way back in 1999, no concrete effort was made to evolve a consensus. Crop burning has been an issue for more than a couple of years with 35 MT of paddy burnt in Haryana, Punjab and Western UP. Yet no policy framework has been evolved. Economic Survey has only come up with a suggestion of imposing stiff penalty for crop burning. While welcoming it, I would ask the Government to frame the rules for immediate and strict implementation. Standard of education is poor. Roughly 40 to 50% of rural children in grade 3 to 8 cannot meet the basic learning standards. Economic Survey has warned that climate change could adversely affect farmers' income by up to 20-25% in the medium term. When we listen to the Presidents' Address, which is nothing but a statement of activities of the Government, it seems that everything is okay. There is no farmers' distress, unemployment is not there, economy is booming, demonetization and ill-conceived GST has not affected any strata society. In fact, there is uncertainty in the economy. This is nothing but fooling the people of the country. The situation is exactly to the contrary. I would like to explain a bit here. Modiji, was talking of 'Acche Din'. Has anyone seen 'Acche Din' in the last 31/2years? When industrial, agricultural, GDP and job growth, apart from other yardsticks, are down, common man, labourers, unorganised sector, agriculturists, farmers, small scale sector, name anyone, they have been undergoing a lot of trauma and anguish because of the wrong policies being pursued by the Government. It is claimed that foreign investment has increased from $36 billion to $60 billion during the last year. How has it lessened the burden of the lowest strata of society? How has it converted into providing employment? It seems there is a big gap between what it states and what the ground reality is. In the Address, it is stated, "the Government is committed to doubling farmers' income by 2022”. Is it not a rhetoric or jumla? What has this Government done to double farmers' income in the last 4 years, and which it has promised in its election manifesto in 2014? Agriculture is the life line of the country. Has the Government taken care of it in the last 3 years or so? If yes, why should there be farmers’ distress and farmers committing suicide in every 30 minutes? This is what The Hindu 2017 November news item says. Who is to be made responsible for this tragic state of affairs of farmers and agriculture in the country- the Government or the Opposition? Should not the Government hang its head in shame? Is it not a blot on the image of the country? What efforts have been made in the last 31/2years to address farmers’ distress? Modiji has promised cost plus 50% of MSP; he has also promised 2 crore employment every year. He also promised Rs.15 lakh to be deposited in each citizen’s account. He and his Government have been indulging in rhetoric. The end is nearing for the Government. People have given an indication in the byelections in West Bengal and Rajasthan. In essence, the first part of Budget session is exactly 4 working days. Is it not a mockery inflicted in the Parliamentary form of Government? Is Government not shying away from legislative scrutiny? Is the Government thinking on the lines of minimum Parliament, maximum Governance? The Government has not made its stand clear on long-pending Women's Reservation Bill. I am disappointed with the President's Address and I am sure the people as well as Opposition parties and some of the alliance partners of NDA too are.

Speaker: SHRI KALYAN BANERJEE(SREERAMPUR)
Speech: Hon. Deputy Speaker Sir, I really give you my thanks for giving me a chance to deliver my speech on the Motion of Thanks addressed by the President of India to the Parliament. Hon. Deputy Speaker, Sir, as we know, under the constitutional scheme itself, the President of India has to deliver the speech on the basis of the written speech approved by the Cabinet. Therefore, this is a speech effectively of the Central Government consisting of the Council of Ministers. If we go through the speech, rosy pictures have been given which are far behind from the foundational fact itself. Only for the publicity, contents of the speech have been made. Sir, I will go one by one point. First, the hon. Prime Minister of India during his Independence day address laid out his vision of a new India where the youth of our nation will become key stakeholders in building the India of the 21stCentury. India’s rate of employment has declined and job creation has not kept up with the growing working age population. Over 30 per cent of our youth aged between 18 and 29 years in India are not in employment, education or training. In 2012-13, the unemployment rate was 12.09 per cent. As per the Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development, youth unemployment rate for five years average stands at 15.50 per cent and in the last two years, the average is 18.10 per cent, though it is ranked as the 25thworld’s lowest unemployment rate. As per the World Bank Report, India’s unemployment rate has increased to 3.60 per cent in December, 2017 from the previously reported number of 3.50 per cent in December, 2016. India’s population will reach 1,360 million people in March, 2018. The country’s labour force participation rate dropped to 53.79 per cent in December, 2017. More significantly, the average unemployment rate in 2017 stands at 4.89 per cent where in urban, it is 5.47 per cent and in rural, it is 4.59 per cent. As on 28thJanuary, 2018, it stood at 6.02 per cent comparing with urban at 7.42 per cent and in rural at 5.29 per cent. Sir, the employment, as promised by the Government since 2014 has not been created or the vacancies have not been filled up in different Public Sectors including Railways. Jobs have been destroyed because of the wrong decisions including that of the demonetization. According to ILO’s latest report, the number of jobless in the country will increase to 18.6 million in 2018 and 18.9 million in 2019 against 18.3 million in 2017. 17 00 hrs It has been noticed that over 3.7 crore of 13 crore jobs in the informal sector of the economy have been lost due to demonetization. While the declared purpose of demonetization was to penalize those among the rich who evade taxes, in reality it hit the poor people in the informal sector, and almost 80 per cent of whom lost their source of livelihood. But ill-prepared monetary measures cut the GDP growth rate down to a low of 5.5 per cent from the predicted almost seven per cent. Economist Amartya Sen considered this act of demonetization as a deprivation of freedom of the Indian people. I quote Prof. Sen: “Demonetization is despotic action that has struck at the root of our economy based on trust.” Sir, sellingSingara,means,pakodaby educated unemployed youth is not the pride of the nation. Prime Minister is the son of a tea seller but tell us, during four years how many tea sellers’ sons have got employment in the country itself. What provisions have been made by him? We want to know that because all the time he speaks that I am a son of a tea seller. Yes, we accept it. By dint of his labour he has come to this level. Now I am coming to Jan Dhan Yojana. … (Interruptions) You must have a degree of tolerance. You must learn the degree of tolerance. Georgetown University Professor Sumit Agarwal and his co-authors studied the account activity in 1.5 million PMJDY accounts from August 2014 to May, 2015 and they stated that 81 per cent of the new consumers did not make any deposits in the first six months. According to a paper published in May, 2017 by Manuela Kristin Gunther from the Overseas Development Institute, 90 per cent of the Indian households have at least one bank account which has also opposed to the Government’s claim of over 99 per cent. Where from these accounts came in Jan Dhan Yojana? What did the Reserve Bank of India say? The Reserve Bank of India also noted in one of its recent papers that Jan Dhan accounts saw “unusual cash deposits” during demonetization as they received additional deposits of Rs.59,810 crore during the period from November 8 to December 31, 2016. The idea of demonetization was aimed at eradicating the black money but the Government failed to do so. Whereas only 99 per cent of the scrapped currency notes came back to the banking system with one per cent loss which brought down India’s GDP growth by almost one per cent. November 8, 2016 is and will always remain seared into the memory of every Indian citizen. The entire range of farming, construction and informal sector which run on a cash basis, and they affect the vast bulk of the population which particularly hit the poor and the vulnerable people The Government had to receive a lesser dividend from the Central Bank as compared to what it received in previous Financial Year. RBI transferred a small amount of Rs.30,659 crore as dividend to the Government for the year ended June 2017, which is less than half of what it gave the Government a year ago, that is, in 2016. Sir, Amartya Sen says Only an authoritarian government can calmly cause such misery to the people — with millions of innocent people being deprived of their money and being subjected to suffering, inconvenience and indignity in trying to get their own money back. Now, I come to farm and farmers. India is an agrarian country with around 70 per cent of its people depending directly or indirectly on agriculture. In a Press Information Bureau report dated 9 May, 2017, it is clearly mentioned that as a result of very good rainfall during monsoon of 2016, the country witnessed record food grain production in the current year. The production of sugarcane was estimated at 36.03 million tonnes, which is lowered by 42.42 million tonne This clearly indicates a dip in collection of indirect taxes. Now, there are three causes for that. The first is the twin shock of demonetisation and GST. The second one is the twin balance-sheet problem of massive non-performing assets of banks which have been weakening India’s banking system. First, by demonetisation, the Government killed formal sector. Then, it came to small and medium enterprises with a premature GST launch without any home-work. That is why, small-scale industries have suffered a lot. Sir, now I am coming to a very important aspect. In our constitutional scheme of things, the President of India acts on the basis of the advice of the Council of Ministers. Similarly, the Governor of a State has to act on the basis of the advice of the State Government. Otherwise, a Governor has to act only on the basis of the advice of the State Government; a Governor cannot act on his own. That is the basic structure of the Constitution. Let me read Article 163(1) of the Constitution: “There shall be a Council of Ministers with the Chief Minister at the head to aid and advise the Governor in the exercise of his functions, except in so far as he is by or under this Constitution required to exercise his functions or any of them in his discretion.” I am saying this because today we see the… * * of West Bengal writing a letter through the Additional Chief Secretary to the Governor to the Divisional Commissioner of Malda Division.
