This is an attempt on the part of the…*to erode the federal structure of the country. There must be a degree of tolerance. THE MINISTER OF CHEMICALS AND FERTILIZERS AND MINISTER OF PARLIAMENTARY AFFAIRS (SHRI ANANTHKUMAR): Sir, I want my dear friend, Shri Kalyan Banerjee, to yield for a moment. He is a learned advocate, lawyer representing in many cases in the hon. Supreme Court also. He knows that the Governor’s conduct cannot be discussed and debated in this House. Therefore, I would request you that whatever is objectionable, it should be removed from the record.

Speaker: HON. DEPUTY SPEAKER
Speech: I will go through the record.

Speaker: SHRI KALYAN BANERJEE
Speech: No, not at all. I am producing the document. Where will I speak? I will speak here. If the… * * function is extra-constitutional, I will point it out in the Parliament itself. The entire nation must know as to how the Governor of West Bengal is functioning extra-Constitutional after committing a grave breach of the Constitutional provision. He is not above the rule of law. Neither the Governor nor the President of India, with great respect, is above the rule of law or the Constitution of India. No, they are not. Therefore, they should act accordingly. He should know about it as he is also a very good lawyer. I do not know why he is doing it after being aware about the law. Is it at the instance of someone that he is doing it? This is something that needs to be answered. It is there in the document, and I am talking on the basis of the document only. Now, as regards expression of freedom of speech, we are losing our degree of tolerance. Article 19 (1) (A) of the Constitution of India gives the right to make our expression. I may not like hon. Parliamentary Affairs Minister’s contentions and he also may not like whatever is my contention, but both of us must know the degree of tolerance and this is our country. What is going on all over the country? For one movie ‘Padmaavat’ the Supreme Court has passed an order. The Censor Board has cleared it and the Supreme Court has cleared it. Where all has this vandalism taken place? It is only in the BJP-run States where vandalism has taken place. This is really an attempt on the part of these persons to throttle the right protected under Article 19 (1) (A) of the Constitution of India. A very popular slogan is being given of ‘simultaneous election’. I see now everywhere that there is a talk about ‘simultaneous election’. I do not know why this is being thrust upon us. I am sorry to say that when this subject is a subject-matter of discussion for a Standing Committee, then how the hon. Prime Minister can go on saying everywhere about ‘simultaneous election’? In our country, people cast vote, and select their representative for a period of five years. Can anybody curtail that Constitutional right? In our country, kindly see, in 1984, there was a Government where one single Party was in majority; in 1989, there was no majority; in 1991, there was no majority; in 1996, there was no majority; in 1998, there was no majority; in 1999, there was no majority; in 2004, there was no majority for a single-Party; in 2009, there was no majority for a single-Party; and in 2014, only a single-Party can run the country itself. There are different States, and we do not know when in one State there may be allies who may fall apart. Let me give an example. Suppose, in 2019, all elections are held in every State and the Parliament. Now, if in 2019, a Government comes and the number one Party is not having the majority and in 2020 other allied Parties withdraw their support, then will there be election in 2020 in the Parliament and all the States? Can it be done? Can you take away this right? You are thrusting something, which really hits the basic structure of the Constitution. We are really debating about it. I am sorry to say, but how this can be made a part of the speech of the hon. President? I am really very sorry. When a Standing Committee is examining a matter, then one should refrain from passing comments on the same. Sir, I am going to tell you a very important point. Let us say that in 2019 the Parliament election is coming. Someone is saying that it is not in 2019, but get ready for elections in November-December 2018 itself. It is very nice. Get ready in 2018. Let the Prime Minister show one example. Along with Parliament elections, let the BJP hold elections in all the States where the BJP is the ruling party, including Uttar Pradesh, Gujarat and Assam. Let him show the example. We want to see the example set by the Prime Minister of this country. This lecture will not do. Let him do it. Let him show his spirit. Let the Prime Minister show his spirit and enthusiasm for holding elections for Parliament along with all the BJP ruled States including Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and Assam. It is stated that charity begins at home. Let the charity begin from the Prime Minister’s Party; let him hold simultaneous elections in all the BJP ruled States including Uttar Pradesh, Gujarat and Assam along with the Parliament elections. Let us see. We want to see. Now I come to the Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana under which poor got LPG cylinders for free but they cannot afford gas refills. Data shows year on year consumption increases of LPG from nine per cent to 9.8 per cent, from 2015-16, and from 2016-17. While the increase in the LPG customers during the same period rose from 10.2 per cent to 16.2 per cent, and in almost in 95 per cent cases, customers are not returning for a refill after receiving the connections and cylinders free of cost. This is probably attributable to the high cost of even a subsidised cylinder. That is the net result. You are giving the connections. हमने तो कनेक्शन दे दिया , सभी जगह गैस पहुँच गई , गैस तो चल रही है। Where is the refill? गैस खत्म होने के बाद वह सिलेंडर ऐसे ही पड़ा है। उस सिलेंडर को देखने जाने के लिए पार्लियामेंट अफेयर्स मिनिस्टर को टाइम नहीं मिला है। कितने सिलेंडर ऐसे ही पड़े हैं , यह देखने का माननीय संसदीय कार्य मंत्री जो को टाइम नहीं मिला है। Now, the question is not about the targeted free distribution of LPG connection, but it need to be looked into as to whether this scheme has actually been successful or not. Under the Swachh Bharat, what has happened? Nothing. Thousands and thousands of crores of rupees have been spent on the advertisements showing the hon. Prime Minister; nothing more than that. Only one day he goes for the Swachh Bharat campaign… झाड़ू लगाने के लिए एक दिन जाते हैं , प्रेस वाला वहाँ फोटो खींच लेता है। With the Minister, photograph will come. On the next day, Sir, you go there, you find garbage; nobody is there to clean; no one from his Party is there to clean. This is only for the purpose of publicity. All over India wherever you go, you find a photograph. How much money has been allocated for Swachh Bharat? Out of that money, how much has been spent on publicity? That is my question. Finally, under the Pradhan Mantri Mudra Yojana, all the loans are granted for the tune of Rs.10 lakh. This amount has been sanctioned after 8thApril, 2015, and for income generating activities other than farm, and also related under the Prime Minister Loan Scheme, under which each Bank has a different interest rate for providing mudra loans. It also depends on the person of business who applying for the loan. If you have a good loan history, then you will get loan, at better interest rates. If you are new, then you will have to struggle a little bit. Under Mudra Shishu Yojana, banks are providing loan up to Rs.50,000. It is a scheme under which banks are charging interest rates which is around 10 to 12 per cent. For whom? Is it going to benefit the poor people? You are charging 10-12 per cent interest. The Central Government is not providing interest-free loans under PMMY. Let the hon. Prime Minister deliver the speech. It is nice that the hon. Home Minister is there. Through him, let him declare that all the loans would be free and no interest would be charged for any farmer. Let him declare and let us see his courage. Through publicity and big words, nothing can be done. Sir, I will be finishing my speech with one quote from the Martin Luther Kind Jr. “We need leaders not in love with money but in love with justice; not in love with publicity but in love with humanity.” But, in our country, today’s leader is in love with publicity, not in love with humanity. Now, we need a leader in our country in the near future who will run the country with humanity keeping respect to the Constitution itself, not for his own advertisement. * * SHRI P. KARUNAKARAN (KASARGOD):Though we consider the Address as the President’sspeech,whichshouldnotbegivenanyspaceforvoting, it is really a declaration of the present government with regard to the variousissues. While I welcome the Address by our Hon'ble President, I would like to give my suggestions on various issues. There are various serious issues which are not dealt with in the Speech made by our President. The Executive, Judiciary and Legislature are the main three pillars of our democratic system. These three institutions have to work in a better way to protect our democracy. In recent times, there are some serious issues concerned with judiciary where four judges of Supreme Court (Justice J. Chelameswar, Justice Ranjan Gogoi, Justice Madan Lokur and Justice Kurien Joseph) had to come forward and address a press conference differing with the views of Supreme Court. They said they had given a letter to the Chief Justicetwo months back in connection with thefunctioningof Chief Justice of India. They even said that they would place these matters before the people i.e. to save the democracy of thecountry.Themainissueiswithregardtothedeathof JusticeLoya,aCBIJudgewhowashearingacaseofencounter killingand it was also connected with Shri Amit Shah, All India President of BJP.Idon’twanttogointothedetailshere.Suchavery seriouscasewastransferredtoabenchofjuniorJustice.This isoneoftheissuesraisedbytheseJustices.Butinthespeech made by our President, nothing is said about this very serious issue of judiciary. two months back in connection with thefunctioning functioning of Chief J The burning issue of common people in India is the price rise. This government has failed to control the price rise though they had promised it in their election manifesto and earlier in the budget speeches. The main reason for the price rise is the uncontrolled prices of the petroleum and diesel. In the international market, the price of crude oil has come down drastically. The benefit of this price reduction is not transferred to the common people. The Government has increased excise duty 17 times. That is the main reason for the price rise of essential commodities. But, as a result, prices of almost all essential commodities have gone up. Since the excise duty imposed benefits has gone to the oil companies. But nothing is mentioned about this price rise which is the common man's issue in the speech delivered by our President. When the NDA Government came to power they promised that 2 crores jobs would be given to the unemployed youth. Four years have passed, 8 crore jobs has to be given by the Government according to their promise. But only 8 lakhs employment opportunities have been created. So, the claim of the President that his Government is going to give more jobs to the youth is baseless. The other major issue of the nation is the farmers’ suicide and their problems. Hon. President said that in the year 2022 the income of the farmers would be doubled. It is surprised to note that the period of this Government is going to expire within one year. So, what is the right of this Government to speak about the year 2022? Government has to take immediate steps to give relief to the farmers and write off their loans, which is one of the reasons for the suicides of the farmers. Now, they promised 50% of the MSP of coast of production but in their election manifesto they had said they would be ready to give 150% of MSP but the same has not been implemented. So, the promise is made with regard to the farmer's welfare is not convincing. Hon. President said much about the welfare of the women, but not a single word is used with regard to the Women Reservation Bill which is pending. Government got the highest majority, then what is the reason for not bringing the promised Reservation Bill. It shows that baseless and hollowness promises to women. Every day we hear about attacks on women and children, but what concrete action Government has taken. Nirbhaya Fund is not spent and Nirbhaya Centres haven't opened in various parts of the country. SCs/STs and other backward sections have been neglected for a long time. The allocation of SCs/STs is only 1.6% of the GDP, but their population is 25%. This is another valid example of their attitude towards SCs and STs. In recent times, our nation faced serious attacks against the secular ideas and organizations. The famous writer Shri Kalburgi, Vice Chancellor of Karnataka University, the progressive writer Shri Pansare and Shri Narendra Dabodkar, the journalists, Gauri Lankesh and many other scholars and writers were threatened and even killed. This is really a challenge before our nation. But, it is unfortunate that President is silent about these serious issues. The figures quoted by our Hon'ble President with regard to the economic growth are unrealistic. The demonetization and GST have weakened our economy as pointed out by many of the great economists and political leaders, but Government is not ready to recognize these mistakes. Growth rate has gone down, inflation is increasing. The gap between the poor and the rich is widening. Though Government say that we are going towards a new India and glittering India, but result is negative. So, while I welcome the President's Speech, I reserve my criticisms. * * श्री रवीद्र कुमार पाण्डेय ( गिरिडीह ) : मैं आदरणीय राष्‍ट्रपति महोदय के अभिभाषण के पक्ष में अपने विचार व्‍यक्‍त करना चाहता हूं। महामहिम ने अपने अभिभाषण का प्रारंभ इस सरकार की संविधान के प्रति प्रतिबद्धता को बताते हुए किया है। बाबा साहेब की सामाजिक एवं आर्थिक जनतंत्र को अमली जामा यही सरकार पहना रही है। स्वच्छता अभियान में शत - प्रतिशत घरों में शौचालय एवं घर - घर में " उज्जवला योजना " के तहत एलपीजी , महिला सशक्तिकरण एवं सामाजिक जनतंत्र का द्योतक है। महिला स्वाबलंबन एवं देश की आधा आबादी के चहुमुंखी विकास के लिए सरकार प्रतिबद्ध है। सदियों से इस देश में हमारी मुसलमान बहनें " तीन तलाक " से सतायी जा रही थीं। धार्मिक तुष्‍टिकरण के नाम पर पिछली कई सरकारें इस मुद्दे पर चुप्पी साधे थीं। इस सरकार ने " वाक द टाक " को सही साबित करते हुए ," तीन तलाक " के खिलाफ बिल लाया है। महिला - सशक्तिकरण का इससे बड़ा उदाहरण क्या हो सकता है। एनडीए की इस सरकार ने महिलाओं के उत्थान में , प्रगति में कोई भेदभाव नहीं किया है। " बेटी बचाओ , बेटी - पढ़ाओ " ने आंदोलन का रूप ले लिया है। बेटियां मुफ्त साइकिल , मुफ्त ड्रेस एवं मुफ्त किताबों के साथ स्कूल की पढ़ाई कर रही हैं। मैटरनिटी बेनेफिट एक्ट का संशोधन कर छुट्टी को 12 हफ्ते से 26 हफ्ते कर दिया गया है। आदरणीय राष्‍ट्रपति महोदय ने इस सरकार की किसानों के प्रति दायित्व निर्वहन को बताया है। किसान इस सरकार के मूल सोच में हैं। उनकी प्रगति , उनकी मदद , उनकी समस्याओं का निदान सरकार की प्रमुख मंशा है। किसानों की वार्ऐिाक आय को दोगुना करने के लिए सरकार प्रतिबद्ध है। " प्रधानमंत्री किसान संपदा योजना " , " जन - धन योजना " एवं " प्रधानमंत्री मुद्रा योजना " मील के पत्थर साबित हुए हैं। जिस यूरिया के लिए किसान मारे - मारे फिरते थे , इस सरकार ने कभी यूरिया की कमी नहीं होने दी है। पिछली सरकारों में गरीब एवं किसान , बीमा का प्रीमियन नहीं दे सकते थे। इस सरकार ने 1 रुपया प्रतिमाह की योजना लागू की - प्रधानमंत्री जी के " सुरक्षा बीमा योजना " , " जीवन ज्योति योजना " एवं " फसल बीमा योजना " ने किसानों एवं गरीबों के लिए सुरक्षा कवच का काम किया है। राष्‍ट्रपति जी ने इस सरकार के " एकात्म मानव - वाद " के प्रति समर्पण को दोहराया है। प्रातः स्मरणीय पं . दीनदयाल उपाध्याय जी के गरीबों एवं पिछड़े वर्ग के उत्थान के सोच को यह सरकार साकार कर रही है। " सौभाग्य योजना " से बिजली , " ग्राम सड़क योजना " का फैलाव एवं " खाद्य सुरक्षा योजना " का ठीक तरीके से अनुपालन गरीब तबके के प्रति सरकार की सर्वोच्च प्राथमिकता दर्शाती है। सरकार ने अल्पसंख्यकों के तुष्‍टिकरण एवं उन्हें वोट के लिए डरा कर इस्तेमाल करने वाली राजनीति को ठेंगा दिखाया है एवं उन्हें आर्थिक विकास , सशक्तिकरण एवं स्वाबलंबन के रास्ते पर बढ़ने में मदद दी है। "" नई रोशनी "" , "" सीखो और कमाओ "" जैसे स्कीम जबरदस्त लोकप्रिय हैं। राष्‍ट्रपति महोदय ने इस सरकार की आम - जन , गरीब तबके , व्यापारी तबके , कामकाजी लोग , सभी को साथ लेकर चलने की प्रतिबद्धता को दोहराया है। यह सरकार "" एक - भारत , श्रेष्ठ - भारत "" के परचम को दुनिया में लहराने में सक्षम है , सतत प्रयत्नशील है। भारत के हर तबके के लोग , हर धर्म के लोग , हर प्रांत के लोग , इस सरकार के साथ हैं - चुनावी विजय - रथ इसका प्रमाण है। जय हिंद। * * SHRIMATI MEENAKASHI LEKHI (NEW DELHI):To eradicate discrimination against daughters, my Government had introduced the 'Beti Bachao Beti Padhao' scheme. Seeing its positive results, the scheme has been extended from 161 districts to 640 districts. Beti Bachao Beti Padhao scheme that addresses the issue of declining Child Sex Ratio, is yielding encouraging results. Beti Bachao Beti Padhao (BBBP) is currently being implemented in select 161 districts. The Government has also taken a big step by amending the Maternity Benefit Act. It now provides for 26 weeks of paid leave in place of 12 weeks. Working women will now be able to devote more time towards their new born children during their crucial formative years. Under the Sukanya Samridhi Yojana, launched with an objective of ensuring a secure future to girls, over one crore accounts have been opened and an amount of over Rs. 11,000 crore has been deposited. As per the latest data, on July 21, 2017, 1.1 crore accounts have been opened with deposits amounting to Rs. 15,849 crore. My Government has tabled a Bill on Triple Talaq in Parliament. I hope that the Parliament will soon pass it into a law. The law on Triple Talaq, once enacted, will also enable Muslim sisters and daughters to live a life of self-respect with courage. Keeping in mind the objective of women's empowerment, for the first time since independence, the restriction on women above 45 years of age to perform Haj Pilgrimage unaccompanied by their male relatives has been removed. This year, more than 1300 women are going on Haj pilgrimage without Mehram. Launched on May 1st in Ballia, Uttar Pradesh, the Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana (PMUY) scheme aims to provide clean cooking gas via free LPG connections to 50 million BPL women, with 15 million connections to be provided within the current financial year. "I am sure all of us remember seeing women burning wood to cook food. They and their children had to go through the pain of breathing polluted air. My Government has started the scheme of Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana (PMUY) which has till date provided 3,30,00,000 free liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) connections to below poverty line (BPL) women." The President has also talked about the Government working towards providing ample maternity leave to pregnant women. Highlighting financial restructuring in favour of women, Hon. President said, "In 2012, there were only 28% women-held saving accounts which have increased to 40% now. We need to uplift our women. The country has taken up schemes to promote the usage of toilets. My Government has formulated policies to help construct common as well as private toilets in the rural areas. This not only helps the country in being cleaner but provides a sense of social justice to a woman. The Government has also set a target of providing of 2 crore toilets under the Swachh Bharat Mission in 2018-19 which directly impact the safety of women and girls.

Speaker: SHRI BHARTRUHARI MAHTAB (CUTTACK)
Speech: Hon. Deputy Speaker, I stand here today to participate in the discussion started on the Motion of Thanks on the President’s Address by my friend Shri Rakesh Singh. Those four lines of the Motion, the keyword is ‘We are deeply grateful to the President for the Address which he has been pleased to deliver in both the Houses of Parliament assembled together on 29thJanuary’. We have to express our deep gratefulness to the hon. President. As the Address itself is the policy statement of this Government, therefore, we always delve into the policy that this Government has been propounding during the last so many years. But what has happened this year is that, on 29thJanuary, the hon. President delivered the speech addressing both the Houses and on 1stFebruary, the hon. Finance Minister has delivered the Budget. So, therefore, today, you must have encountered that the large number of hon. Members, who have spoken before me, have intertwined the Address of the hon. President along with the speech of the hon. Finance Minister. I will try to confine myself only with the speech of the hon. President because we will be discussing for about twelve hours hopefully on the Budget itself. Before, I delve into the specific paragraphs, I have selected some points for my deliberation. But before I go into these paragraphs, one thing that struck me in the Central Hall is relating to what he mentioned about ‘Adivasi Swatantrata Sangram Sanghrahalaya’ . We have seldom deliberated and discussed the fight that our tribal people have fought during the freedom struggle. Very rarely, we have put up memorials for them. But, at least, in this speech, something has been mentioned. How it is going to be developed is what we will see in the future course of action. But one thing is that Kevadia, Gujarat, on the banks of Narmada where the beginning will start, and the proposal of Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Andhra Pradesh, Kerala, Manipur and other States are also under consideration. I am reminded of the struggle in Odisha. In erstwhile Bonai State, today’s Sundargarh District, the British soldiers wanted to recruit tribals for Second World War. The tribals who were forcefully being recruited resisted. There was a large-scale fight then and hundreds of tribals were butchered. It is called Amco-Simco agitation. The leader was Nirmal Munda. A group of people eventoday observe his martyrdom day. Very rarely the government machinery is involved in it. My question here is, is it only confined to the Munda tribe? Odisha Government of course is doing something for that. But here is a fit case for the Union Government to step in, erect a memorial and support an annual festival over there. There was also a tribal leader in his middle age who had never seen Gandhiji, never heard Gandhiji but was so committed to the ideals Gandhiji propagated that he took part in the struggle and led an agitation for Quit India Movement. He was hauled up by the police; a false case was registered against him and he was hanged to death in 1943. That tribal leader’s name is Laxman Naik. We observe his martyrdom day but he seldom finds place in the national history of freedom struggle. We have to find out about such people and we have to commemorate their sacrifices. I would like to remind this House that Laxman Naik was the only freedom fighter who was hanged to death in 1943. Hon. President has said, “Nation building is a continuous process in which each citizen of the country has a role to play.” Wise words, no doubt! When Benjamin Franklin was asked a question, “What have we got - a Republic or a Monarchy?”he reportedly replied, “A Republic, if you can keep it.” It was as much a comment on ability as it was on intent. Today I may say a Republic was easy to form even in those turbulent years when this country attained freedom, but we are finding it difficult to sustain. A Republic has to be sustained in content. Our founding fathers gave us a republican Constitution but they hoped for a civic rule necessary for republicanism to strike roots. Did not Dr. Ambedkar warn that however good a Constitution may be, it is sure to turn out bad because those who are called to work it are a bad lot? He did not refer to elected representatives alone but to the incomplete project of transforming people into citizens. The concern hon. President expressed while speaking to the nation on the eve of this year’s Republic Day and subsequently while addressing the joint session of the two Houses the other day is, “It is our responsibility to exhibit exemplary conduct before the nation. Nation Building is our collective responsibility.” These are the words of the hon. President. What we see today, what we hear today is majoritarianism, rise of vigilantism, institutional corrosion, etc. A democracy gets converted into a show of numerical strength! The capacity to negotiate and deliberate drowns under the noise ofnumbers. This gives way to anarchic articulation of vigilantism, rejecting the idea of rule of law. I need not explain what has happened in between; some Members have already done that. Both a cause and an effect of this is the all-round corrosion of institutions. Do we not find a competition – this is the sad part of it – among institutions to display their flair for failure? The hon. President in his Address has reminded the nation about working towards achieving robust and inclusive development. NITI – we call it Niti Aayog in Hindi – was formed by the present Government when it came to power in 2014 by dismantling the Planning Commission. The idea was that it would facilitate the State Government and the Union Government to formulate their own plans and programmes and that it would act as a think tank but I would not comment what tank it has become today. Now it is behaving in an arbitrary way. They are insulting the States. A glaring example is that they are identifying 115 districts as most backward districts and asking the States to sign MoUs with NITI. Odisha, Kerala and West Bengal have protested to this. As per the Constitution, distribution of power, development is not in the domain of the Union Government. Why would this Government unilaterally declare some districts as most backward and send prabharis ? From where does this word come? We have heard ‘prabhari’ in some organisations. We have heard about prabharis being deputed by some political parties. But now we have prabharis from NITI and from the Union Government going to the States. Who has coined this word? You are sending prabharis to monitor the development works in the said districts thereby bypassing the Chief Secretary and Secretaries of other related Departments? What is happening in this country? These 115 districts include 30 districts which are focussed by NITI; 50 backward districts selected by an Inter-Ministerial Committee of Officers; and another 35 districts which have been shortlisted by the Ministry of Home Affairs which are affected by left wing extremism. Where are the States? Neither have they been consulted; nor any inputs were sought from the States. So much about the so-called ‘co-operative federalism’. Shri Kalyan Banerjee has just left. I am sure my friend Shri Jithender Reddy will talk aboutit. Odisha has not participated in this adventure; so also, Kerala and West Bengal have not participated. Take the case of Bundelkhand where only one district of that region has been included in this programme, in this idea, in U.P. It is a State ruled by BJP. This demonstrates the lackadaisical manner in which these districts have been selected. Now, it finds place in the Budget Speech of the Minister of Finance. No BJP Chief Minister or Government has the spine to raise objection to this hara-kiri of the Constitution. What we believe in the Biju Janata Dal is that when you keep the people first it is good politics. My Chief Minister, the leader of the Biju Janata Dal, Shri Naveen Patnaik, says, ‘When you keep people first, there is no anti-incumbency.’ Half a century ago, one of the greatest visionary leaders, Martin Luther King Jr. had said, ‘You cannot lead people unless you love them.’ This, to him, is the guiding philosophy. According to him, ‘If you love your people, you would not see the post you hold as a post but as a means to serve the people; you would not see power as power but as a means to transform the lives of people.’ ‘All the negative associates of politics’ – these are the words which my Chief Minister has said – ‘power, wealth, andposition, dissolve into nothingness if you love the people.’ If you work for the people, even in the worst natural disaster, you aim for zero casualty and you end up setting global standards. If you love your people, you do not want anyone without a roof over their head and you end up leading the country in rural housing. If you love your people, you will walk an extra mile to include the most vulnerable sections in your growth story and you end up with the path breaking initiative of setting up Tribal Development Council. If you love your people, you do not want hungry stomachs staring into the night and you end up with the highest poverty reduction in the country. If you love your people, you do not fight for elections, you fight for change and transformation. If you love your people with every intent, every step, every action, every signature and with every breath you will work for them. That is the reason why Odisha stands apart from many of the States, especially those that are ruled by the Treasury Benches. Many leaders go to Odisha saying that सत्रह साल हो गया , अठारह साल हो गया , क्या हुआ ? I will just give some instances. With regard to rural housing, 14 lakh pucca houses have been constructed in ruralOdisha since 2014. The source of this information is the Rural Development Ministry of the Government of India. Odisha is the pioneering State in India which has distributed 6,11,000 acres of land to 4,11,000 individuals rights, title holders and 3,28,000 acres of land to 5,964 community rights, title holders under the landmark legislation of the Scheduled Tribes and other Traditional Forest Dwellers as on 31stOctober, 2017. The source of this information is the Report of the Ministry of Tribal Affairs of the Government of India. We started Mamata Programme to support the pregnant women. Subsequently, year before last, the Janani Programme was initiated by the Union Government. It is a flagship programme of Odisha Government which was launched in 2011 and has benefited more than 30,57,000 women in the State. About 5,63,000 Self Help Groups with more than 67 lakh women have been formed under mission Shakti. Based on NSSO Situation Assessment survey for 2012-13 and 2002-03, farmers’ income doubled in real income terms. राधा मोहन सिंह जी ध्‍यान से सुनिए , हमने किसानों की आय डबल कर दी। Odisha is the top performer with a CAGR of 8.3 per cent. The source is NSSO Situation Assessment Survey of 2012-13. और करना बाकी है। कृषि और किसान कल्‍याण मंत्री (श्री राधा मोहन सिंह): जो इसे नहीं मानते हैं उनको समझाइए।

Speaker: SHRI BHARTRUHARI MAHTAB
Speech: In terms of PDS contribution, Odisha is the third highest contributor for food grain procurement in the country in the year 2015-16. It contributes 10.28 per cent of the total procurement in the country. It contributes 26 lakh metric tonne in the year 2015-16. This contribution was only 2.07 per cent in 2002-03. The source of this information is a Lok Sabha Starred Question of 26thApril, 2016. Poverty has declined.As per the household consumer expenditure data of NSS up to 2011-12, poverty in rural Odisha has declined by 24.6 per cent. इस तरह एक-एक करके डिफरेंट पैरामीटर्स पर जाएं तो काफी जानकारी मिलेगी जो लोग पॉलिटीकल स्‍टंट के हिसाब से कहते हैं कि 17 सालों में क्‍या हुआ। नवीन पटनायक जी ने करके दिखा दिया बीजू जनता दल ने करके दिखा दिया। Therefore, incumbency is not a factor. We do our work because we love our people. Odisha’s GDP growth rate was 7.94 per cent in 2016-17 in comparison to India’s GDP growth rate of 7.1 per cent in the same year. But there are other issues which need to be flagged and one major issue is Mahanadi. हमने पिछले सेशन में बार-बार कहा , रिक्‍वेस्‍ट की , प्‍लीड किया , आर्ग्‍यू किया कि ट्रिब्‍युनल बनाइए। मेरा वाटर रिसोर्स मिनिस्‍टर के लिए पूरा सम्‍मान है , वह कर पाएंगे , लेकिन मालूम नहीं , why was he advised in such a way but at least he committed himself in this House that he will make the Tribunal in three months. The matter was pending in the Supreme Court. You had given an affidavit in which you have gone back on your words and said that you will form a Tribunal. But again you gave an affidavit in the Supreme Court saying that it is not feasible. यहां फिर कहा कि तीन महीने में बनाएंगे। सुप्रीमकोर्ट ने क्‍या कहा , सुप्रीम कोर्ट ने कहा कि एक महीने में ट्रिब्‍युनल बनाओ। What progress has been made? Mahanadi River water dispute is a dispute on which the apex court has already pronounced its decision and had admonished this Government for going back on its words to form the Tribunal. It had asked the Union Government to do it within one month’s time. This was pronounced on 23rdJanuary, 2018 and today is 6thFebruary, 2018. How many days have passed? Today is the 15thday to be precise. Has any step been taken? Does this not show the brazenness in which the Government treats the pronouncement of the Supreme Court of India? Does this notdemonstrate the partisan attitude of this Government towards Odisha? We will wait for the decision of the Tribunal. We are sure it will give a decision in our favour because of the illegality of the construction of the upstream of Mahanadi by Chhattisgarh. But the Union Government which was expected to function in a neutral way is becoming partisan. Why do you not form a Tribunal? Why do you wait for the single unitary tribunal which is still in the womb? Whom are you befooling? The Chief Minister of Odisha on 2ndFebruary, 2018 has again written a letter to the Prime Minister but there is no response. I can only plead in this House for the wisdom of all Members and ask is this the way the Union Government should function? How partisan have you become just because you are going to face elections in some months’ time in Chhattisgarh. The dams are being constructed illegally. Water has been stopped illegally and Odisha is being bereft. What are we asking for? We are asking for a tribunal. At least, tribunal will give a judgment. It will hear both the sides. We have pleaded before the Union Government not to be partisan and you take a decision. The previous Minister said that he has no power. At least, now the Supreme Court has given you instructions and said as per the constitutional provision a tribunal has to be formed. But I am sorry to mention that the Government is yet to proceed. We have heard about triple talaq in the Address of the hon. President. He expressed hope that the Bill will be passed. He will act as per the aid and advice of the Council of Ministers. Triple Talaq Bill has already been passed by this House and it goes against the verdict of the Supreme Court. Talaq-e-Biddat is unconstitutional. There is a need to have a law pronouncing Talaq-e-Biddat as unlawful. We are not against that but the Bill which is pending in the Rajya Sabha needs thorough correction. That Bill to do away with instant talaq is on the way of instant law. A law made in a hurry is bound to be faulty. Can you not incorporate in nikahnama that the Talaq-e-Biddat is not allowed. Can a separation/divorce be on record? If marriages fail, should Governments jail husbands? Marriages are social contracts. There should always be attempt for reconciliation. If the husband is put behind bars on the complaint alone, will there be any scope of reconciliation? The Bill is meant to protect the interest of Muslim women. Have they been consulted inany form before the preparation of this Bill which is a must as per the provision before law making? Any law, before it is made, has to be consulted with the respective stakeholders. That is the practice and provision of the Constitution. The Government has prepared a Bill which is half-baked. This will bring more disaster to the womenfolk of Muslim community than empowering them. I fail to understand as to why the Government is doing it. Congress Government committed a mistake in 1986 and now this Government is committing another mistake. The Government may correct it and bring another amendment removing the penal provision. Let the Government not become adamant. My friend Shri A.P. Jithender Reddy has come out openly about holding simultaneous elections about which the hon. President has spoken and the hon. Prime Minister also has expressed his views positively. The other young `Prasad’, Shri Ravi Shankar Prasad from Bihar, our hon. Law Minister, is going around the country saying that we should debate this. I may remind Shri Reddy, my friend, that all these talks of holding simultaneous elections started from the dinnertable that both of us shared once with the hon. Prime Minister. It has rolled on since 2014, where hon. Deputy-Speaker, Sir, was also present, in different forums. The Election Commission also has come out with an opinion. What is the opinion of the Election Commission? Article 83, article 85, article 172, article 174 and article 356 of the Indian Constitution need to be amended for fixing Lok Sabha and Assembly terms. If today it has found place in the Address of the hon. President, should we not be told about the Government’s view? Why does the Government not prepare a draft and circulate it? Today is the time of the social media, but what is the view of the Government? What is the opinion of the Government. The Government is asking others to debate and discuss the matter. Why does the Government not come out with a draft on this? Let that be the basis on which discussions will take place. The Standing Committee earlier had given a report. If you want further discussion on this issue, let us understand as to what the Government intends to do. Why does the Government not prepare a draft and circulate it basing on which debates and discussions will take place? What is the point of this wishful thinking? Hon. Deputy-Speaker, Sir, the hon. President mentioned about the presence of Heads of States of ASEAN countries during this year’s Republic Day celebrations. It is indeed a special dimension to our world vision. But does it end here? What I have understood is that the principal gain of the ASEAN-Indian Commemorative Summit is to provide for an ample clarity on what our partnerships have achieved and where it should move in the future. As the celebrations and the colourful spectacles have ended, is it not time to begin the hard work? When you stand at the peak of a mountain, you get full view of the path travelled and the road ahead that will take you to the next peak. It is now time to draw up a to-do list? Have the Government prepared it? You have a huge responsibility to shoulder. Republics crumble when Statesmanship stops at showmanship; politics breed fear and institutions fail to strengthen norms and procedures. Recently we celebrated our 68thRepublic Day, seven decades of enjoying the Republic, the fortresses of communities have become more impenetrable. In today’s India nobody can criticise, comment or censure the practices of another community of which she or he is not part of. Communities are beyond debate and criticism. Relations among communities are also marked by mutual suspicion. Caste-community based separation, suspicion and violence ensure that the idea of citizenship become a chimera. Then how can we conceive the idea of public good that would emerge and sustain in a republic? That is the fundamental question before us today. Given the fragmentation of the public and impossibility of common good, all politics and policy making is taking the form of a cynical exercise of balancing competing expectations. Serious casualty in this process is the loss of the idea of common good which is at the core of a republic. Does this Government has any roadmap to build in citizenship, collective responsibility and strive for common cause and public good? The answer is there for everyone to see. How social justice and economic democracy has been strengthened is pouring out in the newspapers daily. The last suggestion that I would like to make today is, our Constitution is instructive. Cannot we make reading of this text compulsory in the classrooms across the country? This is the Gospel. Constitution is the gospel. Constitution is the Gita andConstitution is the Quran of modern Bharat, Sashakt Bharat and Samudha Bharat. Vande Utkal Janani, Jai Hind, Jai Jagannath. * * SHRIMATI V. SATHYABAMA (TIRUPUR): I would like to bring to the notice of the Government the long-pending Railway demands of the people of my Tirupur Parliamentary Constituency. The Government should consider and take appropriate steps for speedy execution of the pending demands. 1Train No. 22476 Coimbatore-Bikaner express can be operated from Erode or Tirupur instead of Coimbatore. Further this weekly train needs to be converted to a bi-weekly train. 2Train No. 16614 Coimbatore- Rajkot weekly train to be converted into weekly-twice train. 3Mettupalayam-Coimbatore passenger train can be extended up to Tirupur. 4Manglaore-Coimbatore fast passenger train can be extended to Tirupur. 5Katpadi-Salem MEMU passenger train can be extended up to Tirupur. There is an urgent need for introduction of Shuttle Train services between Tirupur and Salem via Erode as well as between Tirupur - Palakkad and Tirupur to Tirucharapalli via Karur. It is a long pending demand of the people of my Tirupur constituency that a New Railway line through Mettupalayam to Chennai via Sathyamangalam, Gobichettipalayam and Erode be initiated soon. I take this opportunity to urge the Government to fulfil the Railway demands of the people of Tirupur constituency. The much needed Athikadavu-Avinashi Flood Canal Scheme at an estimated cost of Rs. 1862 crores may be sanctioned on a priority basis. This would help the people of the Kongu region to get adequate water for both irrigation and drinking purposes. Gunderipallam reservoir is situated across jungle stream near Kongarpalayam village of Gobichettipalayam Taluk in Erode district of Tamil Nadu. The splendid and the spectacular view of the reservoir and surrounding area attract tourists and film shoots often takes place here. I urge the Government to release adequate funds for this purpose so that Gunderipallam Reservoir could become a significant tourist centre. In Tirupur, the Postal Department is having a site measuring 1.04 acres and 298sq ft. at Kallampalayam Road. This land is lying vacant for the last several years. Sixteen post offices are located in and around Tirupur within 10 kilometers radius. Rent is being paid for 13 post offices. Though Tirupur head post office is functioning in its own building, it is functioning in a very cramped space. As the building is very old and situated near the railway station, it is not possible to expand Tirupur head post office building either horizontally or vertically. If a new building is constructed, Passport Kendra can also function which will be more convenient to the members of public in and around Tirupur. Therefore, I urge the Union Government to allot sufficient funds for construction of an integrated building for the purposes of Department of Posts and Passport Kendra at the vacant site at Kallampalayam Road, Tirupur. The Keeripallam Odai and Modachur Pallam Odai rehabilitation works for the benefit of the people of Gobichettipalayam and its surroundings need to be executed under the Flood Management Scheme. Moreover, a Water Treatment Plant also to be provided at the tail end of this Odai so that the treated water could be utilized for agricultural purpose as a recycling process. I urge the Union Government to allocate Rs. 55 crores to expedite this very important Keeripallam Odai and Modachur Pallam Odai rehabilitation works in Tamil Nadu. * * SHRI T.G. VENKATESH BABU (CHENNAI NORTH): Hon'ble President in his Address has stated that the Government is committed to doubling of farmer's income by 2022. But in reality, the situation is different. Majority of the farmers in the country are living in debt trap. They are not getting timely credit, quality seeds and subsidy. Most often, they are living at the mercy of money lenders and not protected. In Tamil Nadu, as per the 2011 census, nearly 8.67 lakh farmers have quit agriculture and shifted to other sectors during the last 10 years due to various reasons including huge loss. Moreover, the farmers sell their land to real estate and prefer to work on daily wage. The reason attributed for the plight of the farmers is wrong import policy of the Centre, un-remunerative prices for their produce, industrialization and urbanization, coupled with failure to divert the rain and other waters going to sea to the farmers' fields by linking rivers. In addition, the Government should assist the farmers in educating and promoting the cultivation of organic farming. I am glad to learn that the present Government is committed to empower people belonging to backward classes by providing constitutional status to the National Commission for Backward Classes. I am sure that the Commission set up to examine the sub-categorization of backward classes would submit its report shortly so that the benefits of higher education and jobs can be availed by the most backward sections among the backward classes. It is pertinent to mention here that the Government should consider extension of the benefits of higher education and jobs to the economically weaker section from the general category also without disturbing the existing set up. As regards 'Beti Bachao Beti Padhao' Scheme, out of 640 districts in the country, the scheme is extended only to 161 districts and more number of districts are yet to be covered. The scheme faces challenges due to lack of support from civic bodies, constantly changing administration, obsession with marriage, etc. and these issues are to be addressed to achieve to desired results. The 'Jan dhan Yojana' of the Government helps the poor to open a bank account on their own. However, on the flipside, privacy and security issues have cropped up, and new light is shed on the scheme's susceptibility to frauds i.e. whether the bank accounts opened are actually being used. Additionally, several features of the schemes remain ambiguous. For instance, the promising overdraft facility is left to the discretion of banks, which creates prejudices as banks will avoid such situations that could potentially lead to NPAs. These issues are to be addressed by the Government and then only fruits of the scheme reach the intended beneficiaries. I am sorry to state that the Union Government has recently scrapped the Haj subsidy which was first introduced by the British Government in 1932 for pilgrims as the fund will instead be used for empowerment of minorities for this year. In this connection, I would like to submit that around 1.75 lakh people prefer to go to Haj this year and this decision of the Government will adversely affect their long cherished lifetime dream. At this juncture, I urge upon the Union Government to refrain from the abrupt withdrawal of the subsidy scheme and it can be extended by considering their economic status. As regards power sector, I would like to mention about the Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant (KNPP). Quite often, the two reactors are shut down citing 'Under Maintenance' which has raised safety issues of the project. This has raised concern among the activists that the project was set up with substandard components and needs to put a thorough overhaul. Besides, there is also no clarity of time schedule of the commissioning of Units 3 and 4. The Government of Tamil Nadu is deeply concerned with the plight of our fishermen who are continuously attacked and detained by the Sri Lankan Navy. It is a regular occurrence throughout the year. Their boats, nets and other fishing vessels are capsized by the Sri Lankan authorities and are damaged. Government is also aware that 163 fishing boats and gear, which are essential for fishermen to earn their humble livelihood, have not yet been released by Sri Lanka. Long periods of disuse and the monsoons have condemned the boats and equipment to ruin and the poor fishermen are being subjected to a huge permanent loss. Government of Tamil Nadu is consistently requesting that the only means of livelihood of our fishermen is returned in a refurbished condition by the Centre at the earliest. Besides, immediate action may be taken through the highest diplomatic channels to secure the release of 108 fishermen and 165 fishing boats, including 8 fishermen and 2 mechanised fishing boats which were apprehended on 25.01.2016. Recently, in the early hours of 25-01-2018, it has been reported that 8 fishermen along with their 2 mechanised fishing boats set out for fishing from Jegathapattinam fishing base of Pudukkottai District have been apprehended by the Sri Lankan Navy and taken to Sri Lanka. Besides, there are implications of a new Bill introduced in the Sri Lankan Parliament on 24th January, 2018 with provisions to impose huge penalties on Indian fishermen, who engage in legitimate fishing in their traditional fishing grounds of Palk Bay. New amendments made in the Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Act, 1960 of Sri Lanka during the year 2017 has banned and declared bottom trawling as a punishable offence. In addition, a new Bill named the Foreign Fishing Vessels Bill, has also been approved by the Sri Lankan Cabinet which provides for stringent penalties against fishing in the sovereign territory of Sri Lanka. It is widely reported in the media, that the Bill has been introduced in the Sri Lankan Parliament on 24.01.018 and its provisions were aimed at Indian Fishing Trawlers from Tamil Nadu, the Tamil Nadu fishermen, as well as their fishing gear, while they are peacefully fishing in their traditional fishing waters of Palk Bay. This new Bill has provisions to incarcerate our fishermen for longer periods of time and impose huge penalties, which run up to few crores of Indian rupees. The life and livelihood of our fishermen, who fish in the traditional waters of Palk Bay, will then be left at the mercy of the Sri Lankan Government. This move has created widespread resentment and panic amongst the fishermen of Tamil Nadu, especially amongst the fishermen fishing in the Palk Bay. It is an extremely unfortunate development, at the time when the Ministers of India and Sri Lanka met twice and the Joint Working Group on Fisheries met thrice, to work out a permanent solution to resolve this long pending sensitive livelihood issue. In addition, the Government of Tamil Nadu with the support of Government of India has initiated various proactive measures to decongest the Palk Bay and diversify the 2 trawling fishing effort form Palk Bay into deep sea fishing. This unilateral move by the Government of Sri Lanka has far reaching implications on the livelihood propositions of fishermen from Tamil Nadu and will definitely hamper proactive efforts taken by the State Government and the diplomatic efforts taken by the Government of India. Palk Bay is the historic and traditional fishing area of Indian fishermen from Tamil Nadu. Their historical rights were simply signed away, as part of the ill-advised Indo-Sri Lankan agreements of 1974 and 1976, which also unilaterally ceded Katchateevu to Sri Lanka, without having any foresight or concern for the plight of our innocent fishermen. The stand of our revered Leader Puratchi Thalavi Amma and the Government of Tamil Nadu to abrogate the 1974 Indo Sri Lankan agreement that created an imaginary International Maritime Boundary Line and ceded the Katchatheevu islet along with the potential traditional fishing grounds of our fishermen to Sri Lanka, issub-judicebefore the Supreme Court of India. Thus, it would be fitting for the Government of India to register its strong disapproval of such a move, affecting the livelihood of our fishermen in the Palk Bay, at the highest diplomatic level. I also wish to bring to the kind notice of the Government regarding the pathetic plight of fifteen fishermen from Kannyakumari, Tirunelveli and Thoothukudi Districts of Tamil Nadu, who were arrested and detained by the Iranian Coast Guard. These fishermen were engaged in fishing from the Emirate of Dubai fishing base. They ventured into sea for fishing on 22.10.2017 in two mechanized fishing boats and were apprehended by the Iranian Coast Guard on 24.10.2017, when they inadvertently strayed into Iranian waters. The apprehended fishermen are reportedly detained in their fishing boats in KISH Island, Iran for the past two months. It is ascertained that the Iranian Court imposed fine on these fishermen and the same has to be paid by the fishermen with the financial support their local sponsors from Dubai, UAE. It has been further reported that some of the fisherman needs medical intervention. The prolonged incarceration of these poor fishermen who went abroad for earning their humble livelihood, would severely affect their families and dependants in India. Hence, I urge upon the Union Government to intervene and instruct the Ambassadors of India in Tehran and United Arab Emirates to provide necessary medical attention and to take effective legal steps to secure the immediate release of these poor innocent fishermen from Tamil Nadu. I shall, therefore, urge upon the Union Government to take serious efforts to solve this vexed issue. As regards Swachchh Bharat Mission (SBM), despite wide awareness, the resistance to toilets in villages is considerable. Lack of adequate water/monitoring, unavailability of space, behavioural change are some of the reasons cited for creating hurdles in the success of the SBM. If these are issued, positive results will be looked up. As regards Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY), the Government's target to provide road connectivity to every village by 2019 seems to be a distant dream. Lot of efforts are needed to expedite the process and to attain the desired objectives. Coming to the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (PMAY), as of January 2, 2018, only 9% of the sanctioned houses had been completed under PMAY-Urban and under PMAY-Gramin, only 22% of the target of 10 million houses has been completed. As the PMAY projects are progressing at a very slow pace, Government should focus to expedite the project in a speedy manner and by allocating adequate funds. As regards Chennai Metro Rail, Phase I of the CMRP covers a total length of 45 kms. Its extension from Washermenpet to Tiruvotriyur/Wimco Nagar covers further 9.51 kms. There is a need to substantially expand the CMRP like Delhi Metro. A detailed feasibility report for its expansion along three corridors has been approved by the State Government and included in the rolling plan of Japan International Cooperation Agency for funding. Our late leader, Puratchi Thalaivi Amma had requested the GOI to support the proposed Phase II of the CMRP so that the project is given early approval for commencement. I urge upon the Union Government to consider the State's request on top priority as the Chennai Metro is fast expanding and will ease the burden on road usage. * * SHRI K. ASHOK KUMAR (KRISHNAGIRI): I would like to urge upon the Government to release of Rs 6,655 crores for the various centrally aided schemes due to Tamil Nadu. Tamil Nadu Education Department has not received Rs 4,474 crore from the Centre under various schemes in the last few years. Many education schemes, including post-metric scholarship for SC/ST students had suffered as the State was denied central funds on the ground of exhausting the budgetary allocations. A sum of Rs 1,547 crore has been pending towards the post-matric scholarship scheme for Scheduled Castes and Rs 27 crore for Scheduled Tribes for over a year. The Union Government has to pay arrears of Rs 1,312 crore for the Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA), the'Education forAll'scheme to Tamil Nadu. Under the Rashtriya Madhyamik Shiksha Abhiyan (RMSA), an amount of Rs 1,588-crore is due to be given to the State. I, therefore, urge upon the Union Government to expedite the release of all the funds due for Tamil Nadu without any delay. In my Krishnagiri Constituency, Hosur SIPCOT is located. It is hardly 16 kilometres from Electronic City, Bengaluru. People from all walks of life, from IT professionals to workers of garment industry, more particularly women and contract workers, had to travel to and from daily through the 15 kilometres stretch between Mookandapalli (Hosur SIPCOT area) and Bommasandra Industrial area via Attepalli further to reach Electronics City. The road traffic is very badly affected by heavy vehicular congestion. It often takes an hour or more to pass this 15-20 kilometres stretch because of frequent traffic jams. If the Metro Rail is extended up to Mookandapalli, Hosur, it will be a boon for the people living in borders of both Tamil Nadu and Karnataka, as it will solve their daily traffic hurdles and facilitate them to reach their destinations easily. Commercially this will be very profitable too. I urge the Government to extend the Metro rail services up to Mookandapalli, Hosur to facilitate thousands of people of all walks of life to have hassle free travel and to reach their working destinations quick and safe, cost effectively too. In our country, 300 people are killed annually in human-elephant conflicts and hundreds are injured. The loss to elephants also is equally high and is on the rise. Hundreds of elephants get killed when they breach their territory. The invading elephants fall victim to humans and man-mad dangers like firing, attacking with spears and electrocution or killed in accidents by falling, speeding trains and trucks. Elephant-Human conflict occurs primarily due to encroachments of elephant passages and water bodies by human settlements. Elephants can cause heavy damages to standing crops amounting to a huge loss. This provokes a lethal retaliation against elephants. As a result, elephants are often killed. In Krishnagiri District, Elephant-Human conflicts occur frequently. Elephants are naturally scared of honey bees. Elephants would quickly move away if they hear so much as the sound of a buzzing hive. Beehive fencing is a natural way to stop elephants invading the crops and habitation areas. It is easy to make and it cost very less compared to concrete barriers and electrified fences. People can benefit through the harvest and sale of honey. Bees can also increase biodiversity through pollination and even increase the yield of the crop that they protect. Therefore I urge the Government to promote and provide fund for beehive fences to keep elephants away from crops and human habitats and to save elephants from being victims in the Human-Elephant conflicts.

Speaker: श्री आनंदराव अडसुल
Speech: माननीय उपाध्‍यक्ष जी , संविधान और परम्‍परा के अनुसार दोनों सदनों को महामहिम राष्‍ट्रपति जी संबोधित करते हैं। उस परम्‍परा को आगे बढ़ाते हुए , आज के महामहिम राष्‍ट्रपति जी ने दोनों सदनों को 29 जनवरी को साथ-साथ सम्‍बोधित किया। यह भी परम्‍परा रही है कि दोनों सदनों में उनके प्रति धन्‍यवाद प्रस्‍ताव पारित किया जाता है। मैं इस चर्चा में भाग लेते हुए अपनी तरफ से और हमारी पार्टी शिव सेना की तरफ से महामहिम राष्‍ट्रपति जी को धन्‍यवाद देना चाहता हूँ। साथ-साथ सम्‍मानीय प्रधान मंत्री जी का भी इसलिए अभिनंदन करना चाहता हूँ कि जो वित्‍त परिषद दावोस में हुई , 21 साल के बाद उनको वहां निमंत्रित किया गया। यहां तक कि उनके कर-कमलों से उसका उद्धाटन हुआ। एक बहुत बड़ा सम्‍मान हमें देश के प्रति महसूस हुआ। साथ-साथ 26 जनवरी को आसियान देशों के सभी प्रमुख उपस्‍थित थे। यह हमारे देश का गौरव है। देश की प्रतिष्‍ठा को दुनिया की चोटी पर ले जाने का काम माननीय प्रधानमंत्री जी ने जरूर किया है। इसलिए वह अभिनंदन के पात्र हैं। यहां राष्ट्रपति जी के अभिभाषण के कुछ बिन्‍दुओं पर जाने से पहले मैं एक और बिन्‍दु की तरफ जाना चाहता हूँ। जब पार्लियामेंट का 2014 का चुनाव प्रचार चालू था तो हमारे प्रधानमंत्री जी ने एक नारा दिया था- सबका साथ सबका विकास। तभी हम एन.डी.ए. के घटक दल साथ में थे। साथ में चुनाव लड़े और बहुत सालों के बाद एक परिवर्तन देश में आया। उस समय हम यह मानते थे कि एन.डी.ए. की सरकार प्रस्‍थापित हुई है। 18 00 hrs आगे-आगे चलते यह महसूस होने लगा कि नाम के लिए एनडीए सरकार है , लेकिन यह भाजपा रहित सरकार है , जिसका कारण यह है कि अगर हम '' सबका साथ सबका विकास '' का नारा देते हैं तो सभी को विश्‍वास में भी लेना जरूरी है। हमने यह अनुभव नहीं लिया। 23 जनवरी , 2018 को हमारे शिवसेना प्रमुख बाला साहेब का जन्‍म दिवस था। उस दिन हमारे पक्ष प्रमुख आदरणीय उद्धव जी ने एलान किया कि आगे आने वाले चुनाव हम अकेले लड़ेंगे।
